awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Self-Recovering Certificate Authorities using Backward and Forward Secure Key Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent years have shown the fallacy of Certificate Authorities (CAs); insiders are able to steal master signing keys and impersonate certificates, exploitation of system vulnerabilities and other means of infiltration allow attackers to gain access to CAs and copy their keys, etc. At stake is the mere survival of public key infrastructures as trust in them is bootstrapped from trust in certificates that bind public keys to known identities. The current attack surface exposed by CAs makes trust in their issued certificates questionable. The main problem is the information that a current stolen key leaks about to-be-used future keys for signing future certificates. 

This project introduces a new notion of backward security allowing a CA to revoke newly reconstructed secret keys, which were maliciously modified by an attacker and are known to the attacker, before the attacker is even able to sign valid certificates. The project also provides efficient self-recovery meaning that, in the presence of a powerful adversary, CAs are able to replace revoked keys by a new non-compromised signing key sequence. Self-recovering CAs promise strong security guarantees against the most powerful attacker who can read all digital state and this will have a major societal impact: enterprises and individuals will be able to trust such CAs and will regain trust in public key infrastructures as a whole. Self-recovering CAs eliminate a serious security threat to our economy and society.

por.por_cntn:
The project has broken new ground in our ability to design remote attestation in the presence of an All Digital State Observing (ADSO) adversary, who can observe all digital state present in the secure processor where the remote attestation protocol is executed. This is based on exploiting the following core hardware security primitives/principles:

  • hardware isolation for access control (not for offering privacy) implying that the execution control flow cannot be tampered with 
  • strong Physical Unclonable Function (PUF)
  • a True Random Number Generator (TRNG)
  • irreversible hardware counter

We have introduced and defined a new signing scheme, called OTS-SKE (which has session signing keys together with one universal public key). We realized a Weil pairing based solution and a post-quantum secure solution. Its key generation is assumed to have no adversarial presence; during key generation the PUF is used to obfuscate and store signing keys. During signing the ADSO adversary can observing all digital information that comes out of the PUF and/or storage. The main idea is that a freshness nonce indicates what part of the storage should be de-obfuscated (by means of the PUF) and the de-obfuscated storage can be compressed into a signature. (As a side result we showed how PUF obfuscated storage can be made reliable with up to a 10^{-15} failure probability.)

The above shows the power of computing with access to a PUF: Signing can take place even in the presence of an ADSO adversary who observes all digital information including all digital keys. Nevertheless, the ADSO adversary cannot impersonate a new signature for a different (not yet observed) nonce. In essence we replaced digital keys by the “analogue key” represented by the PUF.

In a slightly weaker model, that of the software ADSO adversary (one without physical presence, who can only remotely attack the secure processor), we show that we can introduce a secure co-processor into the system, and the interaction between the secure co-processor and the attestation processor is unidirectional. That is, the co-processor takes no inputs from the processor and only generates secret keys for the processor to fetch. Our experimental results show that the signing of OTS-SKE is faster than that of Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) used in Intel SGX. 

Our new scheme can be used by Certificate Authorities to strengthen their security posture by being able to withstand ADSO adversaries.

The project, due to its complexity (of cross intersecting many different disciplines ranging from theoretical crypto to PUF and secure processor technology), has only been able to output the above remote attestation scheme/protocol in two eprints (expected to be published as peer reviewed conference papers)
